document.docAuthor: Barahona-Segovia, Rodrigo M., Riera, Pamela, Pañinao-Monsálvez, Laura, Guzmán, Vicente Valdés & Henríquez-Piskulich, Patricia
document.masterDocTitle: Updating the knowledge of the flower flies (Diptera: Syrphidae) from Chile: Illustrated catalog, extinction risk and biological notes

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Updating the knowledge of the flower flies (Diptera: Syrphidae) from Chile: Illustrated catalog, extinction risk and biological notes

figureCitation.captionText: FIGURES 113–116. Sterphus aurifrons Shannon, 1926: (113) resting in a dead wood, Juan Fernández Island (photo by Cristian Pardo) and (114) resting in Rhaphithamnus venustus (Phil.) B.L. Rob., Juan Fernández Island (photo by Hernán González). Sterphus coeruleus (Rondani, 1863): (115) resting in a leave, Los Lagos (photo by Luis Candia) and (116) dorsal view (photo by Matías Barceló). Scale bars = 1 mm.

Chilean distribution. From Maule to Magallanes region ( Fig. 117 ).
Altitudinal range. From coastal to precordillera ecosystems (5– 1,200 m .a.s.l.).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 113–116 .
Sterphus aurifrons Shannon, 1926
: (113) resting in a dead wood, Juan Fernández Island (photo by Cristian Pardo) and (114) resting in
Rhaphithamnus venustus (Phil.) B.L. Rob., Juan Fernández
Island (photo by Hernán González).
Sterphus coeruleus ( Rondani, 1863 )
: (115) resting in a leave, Los Lagos (photo by Luis Candia) and (116) dorsal view (photo by Matías Barceló). Scale bars = 1 mm.

FIGURE 117 . Distribution map of
Sterphus aurifrons Shannon, 1926
(blue circles);
Sterphus coeruleus ( Rondani, 1863 )
(red circles), and
Sterphus plagiatus ( Wiedemann, 1830 )
(yellow circles) in Chile.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Biology and notes.
Sterphus coeruleus
is mainly associated with native forests. It has been observed feeding on
E. cordifolia
(Cecilia Smith-Ramírez, com. pers.) and
L. sempervirens
(R. Barahona-Segovia, pers. obs.). Porter (1932) mentioned this species is present in Aconcagua, which could be an error because it is based on old literature.
Conservation status. LC; AOO = 377,436 km 2 , EOO = 192 km 2 , 40 subpopulations and 44 localities.
